intro: Moquilea organensis, commonly known as the Galápagos moquilea, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its hairy, erect stems and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal areas and is adapted to the arid conditions of its native habitat. Its leaves are alternate and ovate, often covered in fine pubescence. Moquilea organensis plays a role in the local ecosystem by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a habitat for small invertebrates.
